text: I have a question to anyone who is running a profitable bot. My old man is nearing retirement and is constantly telling me he wants to give me money to "invest" in my bots. I am happy to do this but obviously if I take it and make profit and pay the old man his share I am going to end up getting shafted on PC if I ever get that far. To that end I would prefer to give him a bot that he can run himself. My question is, how is this sort of thing viewed by betfair? They would be able to see 2 similarly themed bots running surely. Would they see this as some sort of PC avoidance if it were coming from 2 accounts that were clearly related (same surname living in fairly close proximity etc) ? I am WAY off PC stage and have a lifetime loss of 50K to make back first but I am sure you can see the dilemma. Any thoughts?

elements.text: I have a question to anyone who is running a profitable bot. My old man is nearing retirement and is constantly telling me he wants to give me money to "invest" in my bots. To that end I would prefer to give him a bot that he can run himself. My question is, how is this sort of thing viewed by betfair? They would be able to see 2 similarly themed bots running surely. Would they see this as some sort of PC avoidance if it were coming from 2 accounts that were clearly related (same surname living in fairly close proximity etc) ? I am WAY off PC stage and have a lifetime loss of 50K to make back first but I am sure you can see the dilemma. Any thoughts?

text: I am assuming that most people here are Python devs so maybe a waste of time asking the question here but I will try anyway. I have been a C++ dev on and off for 15+ years but since C++11 and later standards have come out I feel the language is not only dying but is overly complicated now and fast disappearing up its own arse. The C++ space seems to now be filled with pseudo-smartarses who enjoy talking about the language in abstract terms and waxing lyrical about new features, rather than rolling up their sleeves and writing something useful. As a consequence, I am looking to get into another language (not discounting pure C either). In terms of long term career demand, does anyone have any suggestions (everything but C# and Java will be seriously considered)??

elements.text: I am assuming that most people here are Python devs so maybe a waste of time asking the question here but I will try anyway. The C++ space seems to now be filled with pseudo-smartarses who enjoy talking about the language in abstract terms and waxing lyrical about new features, rather than rolling up their sleeves and writing something useful. As a consequence, I am looking to get into another language (not discounting pure C either). In terms of long term career demand, does anyone have any suggestions (everything but C# and Java will be seriously considered)??

text: I love Haskell, have done a few side projects with it and used to attend the Hoodlums meetups at Barclays. More importantly, I found Rust much easier to work with for real projects (better tooling, `cargo` etc.)

cargo
etc.)

text: Too much templating for me. Don't care much for this new "modern C++ design" either. I quit my last job but I contract for them and have been for over 2 years. The only other coder there (who I interviewed and gave the job) is really passionate about his C++. He writes classes and all the methods have just one line - no comments. Hundreds of classes and headers with very little content - I absolutely hate it. I don't care for .cpp files with 20,000 lines of code either but I feel that this ultra compact style is the way things will progress

elements.text: Too much templating for me. Don't care much for this new "modern C++ design" either. I quit my last job but I contract for them and have been for over 2 years. The only other coder there (who I interviewed and gave the job) is really passionate about his C++. He writes classes and all the methods have just one line - no comments. Hundreds of classes and headers with very little content - I absolutely hate it. I don't care for .cpp files with 20,000 lines of code either but I feel that this ultra compact style is the way things will progress

text: Some people love it but I prefer my simpler C++. We did without move semantics for many years - I know optimisation is good and all that but is is REALLY necessary? There are nice things like lambdas and having std::thread as part of the standard library now is very nice.

text: It's a lisp, so similar to other lisps like Scheme and Common Lisp. It runs on the JVM so has complete access to the Java ecosystem (without this I don't think it's a viable language). Immutable data-structures. You don't have the problem of having thousands of tiny classes because the Clojure of modelling data is essentially "use hashmaps". Macros, although that goes back to it being a lisp. It's functional.

elements.text: It's a lisp, so similar to other lisps like Scheme and Common Lisp. It runs on the JVM so has complete access to the Java ecosystem (without this I don't think it's a viable language). Immutable data-structures. You don't have the problem of having thousands of tiny classes because the Clojure of modelling data is essentially "use hashmaps". Macros, although that goes back to it being a lisp. It's functional.

text: My first job was embedded C. I did comp sci but had a particular interest in hardware/embedded - this was about 10 years ago but I remember all of the embedded dev roles were dog shit salary then as well. My impression was that there's actually not a lot of roles available and for people coming from a pure software background there's just too much supply from EEE or other engineering disciplines

attachments.fallback: [March 9th, 2020 1:20 PM] oddsvantage: Also C and assembly being such low salaries. Was not expecting that given the IOT and embedded linux explosion over the last few years. Finding good embedded devs is a nightmare task (at least in my location)
